title: Storm lashing: ‘We’ve seen the worst’
text:
Severe thunderstorm lashes east coast Liz Burke and AAP news.com.au Severe thunderstorm lashes east coast Liz Burke and AAP news.com.au Storms hit Brisbane CBD. Picture: Marc Robertson 
WITH trees down, power out and debris strewn about the Brisbane CBD, the east coast has seen the worst of its major storm damage for the week. 
A severe thunderstorm with damaging winds rushed through the Queensland capital late Thursday afternoon with wind gusts of almost 100km/h, heavy rain and lightning hitting the city. Tree snapping outside @612brisbane - so much wind and rain. No hail (yet). #bnestorm pic.twitter.com/RkSZxjrSVo — Lachlan Mackintosh (@lachiemack) October 22, 2015 
The rapid east-moving storm swept through Queensland’s southeast causing havoc on Brisbane roads and forcing rail travellers off train platforms. 
Energex said more than 5000 homes were without power in southeast Queensland on Thursday evening, including more than 3000 in Brisbane. — Joshua0 (@joshua0) October 22, 2015 
While fallen trees are expected to cause possible traffic delays this morning, Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Michael Paech told news.com.au the worst of the weather was over for Brisbane. 
“Around Brisbane we’ve seen the worst and there’s a much better weekend coming up,” he said. Other Stories
